div.head: THE EXAMINER, OR, Gilbert again≈øt Tennent.
div.p: WHEN I had read over Mr. G. Tennent's three fir≈øt Sermons on Rev. 3‚ñ™3. repre≈øenting the Nece≈ø≈øity of holding fa≈øt the Truth, with the Appendix, relating to the Moravian Errors, &c. I immediately reviewed and compared therewith his famous Sermon preach'd at Nottingham upon the Danger of an Unconverted Mini≈øtry, on Mark 1 ‚Ä¢ 44. And mu≈øt confe≈øs it is as impo≈ø≈øible to reconcile them upon the Principles of Common Sen≈øe, as to unite the two Poles.

But then putting on that Charity which is not ea≈øily provoked, and hopeth all Things, I endeavoured to con≈øider the three Sermons as a Retractation of the Nottingham Sermon; That altho' he did not expre≈øly retract it, yet I would charitably ca≈øt it in this Light, for the ≈øake of Catholick Unity, and becau≈øe it ≈øeems hard for an High Prie≈øt to confe≈øs his Errors even once a Year, tho' he may love to be Father Confe≈ø≈øor him≈øelf, and bring others to the Stool.

But upon Enquiry, it is to be ≈øu≈øpected that Mr. Tennent never de≈øign'd that the≈øe three Sermons ≈øhould ≈øuperceed the other; but that they ≈øhould con≈øi≈øt and travel together like good Companions. For it is plain that after Mr. T‚Äîhad preached the≈øe Sermons at N. York, in April 1742, his Sermon at Nottingham receives a new Edition at Bo≈øton, from the ≈øecond Edition printed at Philadelphia; by which it appears that Mr. T. or his Friends, in≈øtead of ≈øuppre≈ø≈øing it, have been careful to propagate it, as his Ma≈øter-Piece; and indeed it is a Ma≈øter-Piece of it's kind: And not only ≈øo, but I'm credibly inform'd, that he has lately ju≈øtified it, as containing the genuine Sentiments of his Soul; and I'm apt to think he has ≈øpoken the Truth. And no wonder Mr. T. won't abate one Jot or Tittle of it, ≈øince Mr. W‚Äîd has judg'd it an unan≈øwerable Piece: for his Coun≈øel it ≈øeems with many in the≈øe Days is, as if a Man had enquired at the Oracle of GOD. The Queri≈øts, Part III, Page 5, take Notice, that it hath been ob≈øerved that when it is Mr. Whitefield's turn to ≈øpeak, then Mr. G. Tennent is proclaimed the mo≈øt able, mo≈øt eminent Servant of Chri≈øt, and all his A≈ø≈øociates or Party, ≈øpiritual Men, and faithful Mini≈øters of Chri≈øt, &c. &c. And in the Examiner, Pag. 149, it is affirmed, that when Mr. Whitefield preached a Sermon at Philadelphia, he told a numerous Audience, that there were but few faithful Mini≈øters of Chri≈øt in the≈øe Parts; and if he mu≈øt be plain and name them, it was the Tennents and their Adherents: The like he did at Fog's Mannor.
On the other Hand, If their Turn comes to ≈øpeak or write, then Mr. Whitefield is proclaimed the mo≈øt able, and mo≈øt eminent Servant of Chri≈øt.‚ÄîWhen there is ≈øuch an Hue and Cry after Phari≈øees, we would be glad to know, whether it would be ≈øafe for the other ≈øide to trumpet one anothers Prai≈øes ≈øo loudly and highly as this ≈øide doth, without being in Danger of being taken up for Phari≈øees, and having the Crows Eggs ca≈øt in their Teeth? becau≈øe Chri≈øt ≈øaith to tho≈øe Phari≈øees that were offended at him for healing a Man on the Sabbath, John 5, 44. How can ye believe, that receive Honour one of another?

It is plain al≈øo, That Mr. T‚Äît's zealous Advocates here and el≈øewhere, have by way of Charity, di≈øpers'd about the Country great Numbers of the la≈øt Edition, tending to corrupt the Minds of People from the Simplicity which is in Chri≈øt, and to promote that Confu≈øion and ≈øeparating Spirit which he him≈øelf has been in≈øtrumental of rai≈øing in many of our Places; Which the Lord rebuke in his Time. For many are fully per≈øwaded that Mr. T‚Äît's Sermon and Practice upon it, have ≈øown the Seeds of all that Di≈øcord, Intru≈øion, Confu≈øion, Separation, Hatred, Variance, Emulations, Wrath, Strife, Seditions, Here≈øies, &c. that have been ≈øpringing up in ≈øo many of the Towns and Churches thro' the Province for two Years pa≈øt. Who hath been ≈øo in≈øtrumental to hatch the Cockatrice as him≈øelf, tho' at the ≈øame Time he could gravely advi≈øe others to cru≈øh it in the Egg See his printed Letter to Mr. Dickin≈øon. . His Principiis ob≈øta is given out too late in the Day: That is to ≈øay, After Vows make Enquiry, in≈øtead of letting alone Contention before it be medled with.

Whoever will take the Pains to con≈øider the main Scope of Mr. Tennent's Sermon at Nottingham, will find the Principles of it to be ≈øubver≈øive of Go≈øpel Order, the publick Mini≈øtry and publick Means of Education; and what have we more? What could touch the Apple of our Eye like this fatal Blow. It is a Blow at the Root.

Take here by the Way, the Sentiments of the Synod in the Examination, &c. Page 81, viz We look upon Mr. T‚Äî's printed Sermon preach'd at Nottingham to be a notable In≈øtance of their ≈øowing Seeds of Divi≈øion, and we charge him with perverting Scripture, uncharitable ra≈øh Judging of the Body of the Clergy of this Generation in the Lump, and encouraging Factions and Di≈øorders therein; and ≈øay we, This, This, This, and the like Speeches thereunto, filled the Minds of many People again≈øt their ≈øtated Pa≈øtors, &c.

Furthermore, I can't find any Room for rational Chri≈øtian Charity to think that Mr. T‚Äîever intended that his la≈øt Di≈øcour≈øes ≈øhould be interpreted as a Retractation of his Sermon at Nottingham; and therefore as long as he holds two Sett of Principles as oppo≈øite to one another, as the heatheni≈øh Principles of a good and an evil god, and until he makes a publick and ≈øolemn Retractation of that Sermon, it is but ju≈øt and equal to ≈øet Gilbert again≈øt Tennent, and judge him out of his own Mouth.

Moreover, Having reviewed the florid Preface to Mr. Tennent's late Di≈øcour≈øes, ≈øub≈øcribed by Six Reverend Divines, of who≈øe Opinion it's ≈øaid much U≈øe is made in the Country, I ≈øtumbled at the Thre≈øhold again, when I could not find one Word to help out my Charity towards reconciling Mr. T‚Äît with him≈øelf: But they ≈øet it forth as an Epi≈øtle of Commendation of this their dear Brother and his Works without any Exception.

They call his Performance, A Labour of Love and Effort of holy Zeal of One that has learn'd to contend earne≈øtly for the Faith once delivered to the Saints; and with the Light of a wi≈øe Ma≈øter-Builder, on the Foundation which Chri≈øt and his Apo≈øtles have laid. They ≈øay further, When this our dear Brother, who≈øe Prai≈øe is in the Churches thro' the Provinces, vi≈øited us at Bo≈øton, two Years ago, and in the Spirit of the Rev. Mr. Whitefield, entred into his Labours here; it plea≈øed God in a wonderful Manner to crown his abundant Services with Succe≈øs, in the Conviction, and (we tru≈øt) Conver≈øion of many Souls: As therefore the Name of Mr. Tennent is greatly endear'd to us, ≈øo we be≈øeech our a≈øcended SAVIOUR, the Head
of the Church long to continue him for a burning Light, and exten≈øive Ble≈ø≈øing to our Provinces; and in particular to u≈øe this faithful, judicious, and ≈øea≈øonable Endeavour of his Servant, for a Guard and Defence about his own ≈øacred Truths, and his glorious Work in the mid≈øt of us, which too many are ready to ≈øpeak evil of and oppo≈øe.

One mu≈øt be cloathed with Charity down to the Foot to think that the≈øe Reverend Gentlemen had not ≈øeen Mr. Tennent's Sermon at Nottingham, &c. which ≈øtands in direct Oppo≈øition to ≈øome Parts of his Doctrine and Conduct expre≈øt in the≈øe Sermons and el≈øewhere, as I ≈øhall demon≈øtrate in parallel Lines.

If therefore they had well confidered and compared the one with the other, how is it reconcileable with the Simplicity that is in CHRIST, to repre≈øent Mr. T‚Äî as ≈øuch a burning Light, when his Spots are ≈øo con≈øpicuous to the mo≈øt cur≈øory Reader?‚Äî One might expect that if Mr. Tennent had not the Ingenuity to ≈øay, I Repent, that at lea≈øt the≈øe Reverend Gentlemen would have attempted a Reconciliation for him, if they think as Prote≈øtants generally do that Infallibility may mi≈øtake.
